reviewText:
I don't understand the people bashing this game. I'd recommend playing it for longer than 20 minutes before leaving a scathing review.

This is a great game. If you ever wanted to play a management game a la Footy Sim but dont give a s**t about sports, then this is the game for you. I mean, it's not nearly as in-depth as sports management games, but it doesn't need to be. It's got the right amount of everything.

If you are a huge fantasy nerd, (like me) and want a change of pace from your standard RPG, pick this up!
voteText: 40 of 51 people (78%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
I'm changing this review to 'recommend'. The developer has made a lot of positive changes over the last few days - you can tell he's really put some time in, and he is clearly listening to the community and implementing suggestions.

It's still not Baldur's Gate or OOTP, but I think Redemption is at a point now where it's worth $3.99.  My impression is that the dev is going to be improving this for a while longer yet.

I'll keep my original review below so it is still on record, but this applies to the original version that I bought on the release date.

****************************************************************************************************************

For the first five minutes, it looks like this game is going to be great. You review the different characters you can hire, and they have detailed looking descriptions like, 'Derp of Derpville tends to make bad decisions under pressure'.

And then you get to the actual gameplay and there's nothing there at all. You don't directly control the party during the quests, which is fine, but you don't get anything that bonds you to the characters which is really what this game should be about. There's a handful of attributes for each character, but no individual stats or personality to them.  I've just spent over an hour playing, and I can't tell you the name of any one of my characters.

And that bit of detail in my first paragraph about someone not handling pressure? You can't see that, or anything like that, having an effect on the game mechanics at all. Same with morale.

People are saying that this is like an OOTP Baseball for fantasy role playing. Well, I've been playing OOTP for 13 years and games like it for much longer than that. And no... it's not like OOTP in the least. It has very vague aspirations in that direction but it's far too simplistic. It's more like a very basic mobile game that's been converted to PC. You will see everything that this game has to offer in the first 10-15 minutes of play. The artwork is fairly nice, but that doesn't mean anything in games like this.

I hope the devs continue to add depth to this game because the concept is good. But until then I can't recommend it even at this really cheap price.
voteText: 32 of 40 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Redemption: Eternal quest is a game like Football Manager for Roleplaying/Dungeoneering.

You have less, and no direct, influence, just in critical moments. You can heal and train your characters in between quests. You get to make decisions while on a quest: Which path of two are you going to take? Do we enter the ruins or not? Who will go on the quest?

It's quite simple and entertaining, with a nice, narrating touch to it. The music adds to this storytelling atmosphere.
It's like a roleplaying book in its game flow.

The game in its current form entertained me quite a while, trying out specializations and strategies - it helps if you like numbers, though, and keep track of your characters.

The author so far makes regular updates and there is still much which can be expanded and filled with some flesh in this game. Also, access to character information in all screens would help the game, as you wont need a cheat sheet" with your characters next to you while playing.

But all in all it's a pleasurable experience. Casual
date: fun and ideal if you have your head full with other things: Then it will relax and entertain very effectively.\n\nI'd buy it again
hoursPlayed: for its full price. And if it should happen to be on a sale and you like the idea
voteText: just go for it! You won't regret it. It is fully functional and for me

reviewText: Shallow and boring. You just pick from a list of samey characters with different stats that don't really affect much. You send them on quests on a little map thingy with a couple options then it tells you what happened. Even the most challenging options are easily doable on starting chars. There is no inventory or equipment management, all the loot you find with the special names are just fluff for the number of gold pieces you get - which there really isn't a use for other than training and hiring guys, but I don't see the point of that given the starting guys don't seem to have a problem taking on the most challenging places. The most complex thing that happened was a random event where a character got pissy with me and left because he was upset, which was apparently because I kept sending them against challenging places (despite them winning and coming back with great loot every time) and another guy got injured" which simply meant he was off the team for a little while. I bought it from a Groupees bundle
date: where it had the following description:\n\n"Redemption: Eternal Quest is a unique and challenging RPG/Sim where you manage a group of adventurers
recommended: guiding them through thrilling quests and collecting treasure and relics. The difference with this game is you step into the role of managing these warriors
voteText: schooling them
helpfulPercent: making key decisions and watching them grow into legendary heroes.\n\nIt combines roster/resource management with RPG sensibilities
votesHelpful: with a completely random world generated every game and even every turn! Explore Ruins
column16: and engage in combat with a unique card-based system. Use the Prestige from your discoveries to drive your party to even greater heights. "\n\nThat description sounds like an awesome
column17: in depth game. Nowhere did it say anything about it being a soulless casual game with absolutely no depth and no gameplay to be had. Kudos for them saying it was casual on Steam
column18: but they sure tricked me with their previous description. In the future if I buy from groupees I'm just going to cheap out and pay $1 and give more if any of the games are worth a dime.\n\nIf you like shallow
column20: mindless games this might be just what you're looking for - but otherwise get yourself a double cheeseburger from McDonald's
column21:
it's cheaper and it'll last you longer.

-edit- 10/15/15: Apparently my issue with the game being too easy for starting chars to storm through the toughest events has been somewhat addressed by making the starting characters get injured more.

Also

column25: but I am sorry I bought a game and expected it to be like it was described on the page I bought it from. I should have looked up the longer description on Greenlight... and been even more disappointed."

reviewText: True to its name, there is no 'winning'  in Redemption Eternal Quest, just on-going-ness. Given that there isn't really any dynamic play or surprise events, I imagine REQ to be the kind of game that would be popular on Facebook or as a mobile game--in-game purchases, linking with 'friends,' & timing out tasks. If you take all that away, you get this sort of game--not a dull but not compelling enough to return to with any regularity.\n

reviewText: This game probably can't be salvaged. If you like it, more power to ya, but for me this game is a complete waste of time and money. Here are my major gripes:\n\nPacts: For gods sake, how about a pop-up or notification when a pact expires; you know, like a big red flashing thing. This is important. Sure, you can figure it out from the character screen by noticing that there are zero days left, but instead of doing it that way, have big bold red letters that say NO PACT!" Who knows
recommended:
you might even have the game ask if you want to extend the pact and take them to the screen to do it if they say yes.

Interface: the interface is dated and clunky. Quitting the game gives me a a standard Windows confimation box with a Windows ding instead of a custom one. Makes me feel like I've just crashed the program instead of tried to exit.

Stats: What do stats do? As far as I can tell
hoursPlayed: they do nothing because there is no indicator when something happens if your stats helped/hurt you. How about giving me some target numbers and die rolls to show the stats actually at work. Anything less might as well mean you threw random numbers at me at the beginning of the game and never use them again.\n\nCombat: This is the worst offender. Combat is sheer luck. I might as well be flipping coins or playing rock/scissors/paper. How do I know what morale might be before combat. THat sure seems random. How do I know anything about how terrain might affect combat aside from a wag. (If you don't know what a wag is
voteText: the "g" stands for guess). The cards then are not really important since you don't even have a rough idea of what the random modifier may be. While it might make for a crushingly boring game
helpfulPercent: don't give the player any combat choices
votesHelpful: because his choices are really meaningless and completely overshadowed by the randomness. That would be better than giving a player the false sense that there is some actual strategy involved."

reviewText: A good idea of a game where you follow the progression of an adventuring party, one year of their life per turn. Their adventures' random description are nice, but pretty soon they appear... random, and pointless since they don't make sense together. Also, it is pretty rapidly repetitive. You need a lot of imagination to invent some sense out of your characters' story. I'd recommand this game for a bored sunday afternoon if it was free or 1$.

reviewText: I'm having fun with the game. For the same amount of money that I spend on two scratch tickets every morning, it's an interesting game to play. Just to be clear- you aren't the party leader or a member of the party. You're their manager- hiring members, getting them gigs, trying to turn a profit. You do interact on the quests by occasionally making some choices- pretty random, but it adds a bit of fun hovering over which selection to choose. The developer is engaged in the discussion forum, it looks like more components will be coming. Go for it :-)

reviewText: This is an incredibly addictive game.  It just won't let you go, it's always one more turn."  This game isn't a RPG or a dungeon crawler.  The best way I can describe it is a "Adventure Party Management Simulation."  Like sports management games you set rosters

You start by hiring a group of six adventurers and then picking which four of them are best suited to go on quests.\n\nThe quests are a very quick affair.  In some of them you are given choices to decide which path to take.  Some quests involve combat.  Because this is a simulation

reviewText:
i really liked elysium blood games by simprose studios and was offered a key by the developer for this game to try it and review it if i wished to and as it was on my wishlist of course i said thank you very much! :)

the game is text based really but that doesnt detract from it for me personally, i right away took to the game and found it very easy to see what to do and how to play.

to cut a long story short the game is very appealing and easy to grasp but the game is very repetative hence eternal quest in the title, you send your warriors out on a quest they either find treasure or not and fight creatures or not then you repeat this with contract haggling or hiring new warriors or training them to do also.

for me i find this enjoyable repeating what i have learnt how the game works, its not brain draining and i find it relaxing and not stressful and i can watch tv or chat at the same time so huge thumbs up there :)

i have put over 14 hours into the game now so feel i can leave a fair review of how i feel about it and out of 10 with 5 being average i would rate it 7/10.

very cheap price for an enjoyable game so well worth the bargain price!

reviewText:
I didn't expect much from the game as it's listed as a casual game and was fairly cheap. With this considered, this is a very good game if you like casual text and statistic based adventures in a high fantasy setting. This clearly won't appeal to all, but it definitely does to me as I like fantasy settings, detailed stats and management and reading stories and seeing random results based on my management.

Advice - Play this game once through for an hour to get stuck in.  Then start the game again, play through and read every '?' help bubble going.  After one hour you'll know if you like it to keep or want a refund.

Positives:
- You select 6 heroes to manage, each with unique abilities /100. You have to choose carefully what to do with them - rest them to heal or pay for healing? Send them on a quest, or send them to training? Choices will have a decision on morale.  You also have to choose who to hire again for another season of adventuring, and who to fire.
- The quests can go different ways. Either you just get a story reported back, you enter a card game driven battle (simple mechanics of pick 1<3 support cards to play), you get to choose a path to take, whether to open a chest or not, and in some cases this game turns into the TV show 'Strike It Lucky' - choose 'Top, Middle or Bottom' across 3 colums, and try to avoid the 'Hot Spot' aka Trap.  The other two options are treasure or very tough monsters to fight.
- I found myself thinking 'Just one more turn...' (i.e. Adventure).  Always good in a game, the addictiveness.

Improvements required:
- The developer is active in this game so look forward to more community aided improvements that may hopefully increase variety of encounters.
- Could do with Steam achievements and Trading cards, but for the money I pay, it's still excellent value.  Achievements would be a no. 1 improvement for me.
- If you're not into text and numerical games, and like top end graphics and real time action, avoid this game.  This game after all is around a 50MB download!  You have to imagine in your mind what's going on sometimes and how it would play out, something sadly lacking today in a lot of games.
- May get a little repetitive, but again, it's cheap and good for a good few hours of play here and there.
- There is no tutorial or manual, but you don't need one as its all explained within the interface.  As a positive: The interface is actually simple, well thought out, unlike the UI of a lot of games these days. This ones actually intuitive and useful, everything where you want it to be.

Buy it - it's good value entertainment for fantasy and management fans! A very niche market, but good for those who enjoy the niche.  I suspect a lot of negative reviews are from people who don't like that niche or appreciate what the game is attempting to deliver. You need to 'get' this game and what it's about to appreciate it.

reviewText:
This design is best enjoyed by gamers who are fond of both strategy oriented role playing games and spreadsheet based resource management simulations. You view the world from the perspective of an adventuring party’s sponsor/manager.  The focus is on signing up a team of six adventurers from an available pool with an eye towards optimizing your cost-benefit differential and maximizing profits. You select quests from an available menu that grades the encounters as to potential danger and potential profits.

The audio and visual elements are minimalist and your fun factor is almost entirely dependent on how much you enjoy resource management in a Tolkienesque world.  Most of the art work is quite good. The most glaring exceptions are the portraits for your adventurers which cry out for a make-over. Fortunately, you can easily customize the character and creature pictures with your own appropriately sized jpeg files. You can also customize the narratives via simple text files.

Managing your crew through years of adventuring, recruiting fresh blood when needed, providing training for your charges, negotiating contract extensions and selecting quests that best suit your party’s abilities are what this game is all about. Combat and encounters are extremely simple and the real Achilles heel of the design. A more elaborate and skill-based card game for the battles would go a long way towards extending the game’s longevity.

I had fun with the game for about twenty hours before finding myself looking elsewhere. Given the price, that’s a pretty good cost-benefit differential.

reviewText:
Quickie Review (w/updates and edits below):

OOTP for Dungeons.

Ok, maybe not AS deep as OOTP. But it utizes a similar concept, focusing more on strategy and team-building then on actual action itself. It's got the amount of depth one should reasonably expect from a $4 game, though. It is NOT as deep as OOTP by any means.

Manage your team of adventurers and send them on quests. Earn gold, level up, rinse, repeat.

Deal with injuries, contracts, recruiting, scouting, etc.

Definitley worth under $5.

reviewText:
Played the game for about 30 minutes.  I am not really impressed, it is missing the wow factor that would make me want to continue playing any longer.

*During my play through I place my adventurers on many quests and was unable to raise my gold level past 10,000. It was a continual loss of gold, with very little gains.
*You contract your adventurers for 1-4 years. Each quest is a season long, four quests equal 1 year.  At the end of their contract you have to pay for them again or contract a fresh adventure. So if I can't make money and have to pay large amounts of gold for unskilled adventures what the hell is the point.
*If there was a way to allow my adventures to rest without having to send anyone else out on a quest, it was lost in the explaination on how to play.
*Can't equip your adventurers to make them better party members.
*Combat is one sided, set for you to loose.  Even on the easy adventures.
*Apparently all my adventures are stupid.  Random bad luck occurs on every mission causing needless loss of life or permenantly bad statistics added to my characters. (yeah that is fun, instead of character progression, every quest my adventurers suck more)

There are more reasons not to play this game but I am too frustrated to list them all.  I would give this game another try if they update content to make it fun and rewarding.

reviewText:
Redemption: Eternal Quest is a text based game with a team of warriors that fight and adventure on behalf of the player in a fantasy management game, the player can have up to six warriors at a time on the roster and send up to four of them  on each adventure to find hidden  treasure, ancient places of power, monsters to fight and many more interesting random events which can be both good or bad.

Each warrior will have a pact in place much like a mercenary contract stating how much pay they require to work for you and how for how many years that service will be,the fees can vary from one time payments to yearly salary or even a percentage of the money made from treasure that's found along the journey but when a pact ends they might demand a better deal so this part of the game is a lot about balancing the books and deciding whether to have warriors fired or hire more which can be found at the hireling pool, at the end of the day this game is about staying a float with gold so tough decisions might have to be made.

Each warrior also as different stats, traits, strengths and weakness that can help or hinder you through out your adventures, two in particular are combat and dexteritywhich form a score towards the battle card games that use many monster and magic based picture cards with a random score to determin a total battle score, you can use between one to three cards per battle if you have them and the total score must be higher than the enemies score to beat them, up to eight battle cardscan be held at any one time and you can earn them through battles, opening chests and buying them every season.

If you are looking for a management game that isn't about Soccer then give this a try because it's a nice adventure game that uses the power of your imagination.

reviewText:
Redemption: Eternal Quest has been years in the making. This is a fantasy adventure SIMULATOR, not an RPG. It relies mostly on random generated algorithms, similiar to SimProse Studios's other text games. The programmer's main goal was to design an adventure management simulator. This dream has been relealized with pacts (contract negociations).

I have played an earlier version of this game, called Arcadia. Redemption is more complete and has more options and features.

I still would like a pact expiration notice, perhaps a low funds warning, monster card values revealed (at least a range or maybe one card), numbers seem too random, a better end game screen if you lose, adventurer stats probably need to be slimmed down to a handful, and salaries usually just keep increasing. The good news is there are options to turn off settings now for different game experience.

All that said, if you like text games and old school themes, you will like this. There is a lot of fantasy flavor text and tropes we are all familiar. DnD fans should like it.

reviewText:
Ouch.
If you're going to do a text-based video game, you'd be well inspired to:
- avoid using fonts that might distract your attention,
- avoid typos and grammatical wizardry,
- write in proper English,
- ensure the text is always readable, and not cut off because the window is too wide and can't be resized.

Add to this the more than mediocre UI, and I think we've got ourselves a winner.
For further laughs, the runner-up would be the trailer for Lexica (which can be seen on Steam): it's a word game and yet there's a very ugly typo in their promo.

reviewText: A simple hero-management game. Could have a better interface but it's interesting enough to spend some time. Also seems to have some features with little or no influence on the game itself.

reviewText:
An interesting premise: Adventurer Management Simulation
It has some good ideas, Choose Your own Adventure story chains are fun. Unfortunately the ones here are a little short. Adventurers have unique stats and abilities and are always doing stuff at the tavern when you return.

There is the core of a really interesting game here. But it will require some tweaking to make it good.
Keep an eye on it, as the developer seems open to critique.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K72c_wfCWq8
voteText: 4 of 11 people (36%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Highly addictive in the one more turn varity.  Very much like the quests in Space Ranger (1 or 2)?
Combat is auto resolved for most missions, the only input you have is choosing (or not choosing) cards for certain battles.
Healing characters with potions is uber expensive, as is resurrecting dead characters.
Great game to play while watching football or baseball.

reviewText:
Consider this a soft" recommendation.

I can't whole-heartedly recommend it because it's just not that deep and it lacks a lot of polish.

It's got a lot going for it
hoursPlayed: the idea of contracting your adventurers
voteText: etc. It's definitely a management sim
helpfulPercent: but that aspect is pretty thin
votesFunny: but you mostly just send them out and then decide who heals or trains. It feels like it needs more options and more depth
commentsCount:
but what's there is good - it just needs more.

It's very repetitive and often what happens feels as if it's completely beyond your control. The RNG nature of the game feels bad at times.

However
column18:
and you cannot beat the price.

Very good value!

I look forward to more from this developer."
